channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Saudis and Extremism: ‘Both the Arsonists and the Firefighters’
item.media:description: Muslim pilgrims surrounding the Kaaba, the black cube at the center of Islam’s holiest mosque in Mecca. The Saudis’ export of Wahhabism has special cachet because the country is the birthplace of the Prophet Muhammad.
item.description: Critics see Saudi Arabia’s export of a rigid strain of Islam as contributing to terrorism, but the kingdom’s influence depends greatly on local conditions.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE

item.title: Turkey’s Military Plunges Into Syria, Enabling Rebels to Capture ISIS Stronghold
item.description: Syrian rebels, aided by Turkish tanks, planes and special forces, said they had taken control of Jarabulus, the last major Islamic State redoubt near Turkey’s border.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO, ANNE BARNARD and CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Colombia and FARC Announce Deal to End the Americas’ Longest War
item.media:description: A group of Colombian rebels scanning the sky for government aircraft in May.
item.description: The country’s largest rebel group and the government said they had finally come to an agreement to end a conflict that had lasted 52 years and claimed some 220,000 lives.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Utracán Journal: On Argentina Plains, Hunters Feel Besieged by Critics ‘Made of Asphalt’
item.media:description: Daniel Briguez, second from left, during a morning hunt last month in La Pampa Province, Argentina. With Mr. Briguez, and his mastiffs, were his son Franco Briguez, left, Hugo Javier Alfonso, center, and Jorge Fetter and his son.
item.description: Threats to a hunting tradition emerge as animal rights activists, buoyed by their growing clout, say the time has come to put an end to boar hunts.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: After Earthquake in Italy, ‘Half the Town No Longer Exists’
item.media:description: An injured man was rescued from the rubble of a collapsed building in Amatrice, Italy, on Wednesday after a 6.2-magnitude earthquake.
item.description: Dust still swirled about the rubble piled waist-high in the town of Amatrice. Stunned survivors, some still in pajamas, wandered through the streets, unsure what to do.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Hopes Dim for Survivors of Italy Quake; Death Toll Stands at 241
item.media:description: Rescue workers continued their search for survivors in Amatrice, Italy, on Thursday.
item.description: In a rare bit of good news, the death toll was revised downward, from an earlier tally of 247, but the figure could rise again.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: French ‘Burkini’ Bans Provoke Backlash as Armed Police Confront Beachgoers
item.media:description: Armed police officers watched as a woman removed her shirt Tuesday on a beach in Nice, France, after a ban went into effect on “burkinis,” full-body bathing suits designed to accommodate Islamic modesty codes. Such bans have have apparently hit not just women wearing burkinis but others in a wide range of clothing.
item.description: Some politicians began backpedaling as an outcry grew on social media over the apparent public humiliation and ostracism of Muslim women dressed in modest attire.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Explosion and Gunfire Erupt at American University in Kabul
item.media:description: Afghan security forces responding to an attack on the campus of the American University of Afghanistan in Kabul on Wednesday.
item.description: A siege stretches for hours after a bomb-and-gun attack at the campus in western Kabul, and many people were still thought to be trapped.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and ZAHRA NADER

item.title: Kim Jong-un Hails Firing of Submarine Missile as ‘Greatest Success’
item.media:description: North Korean leader Kim Jong-un, in a photo released on Thursday by the North’s Korean Central News Agency, during a test-fire of a submarine-launched ballistic missile.
item.description: The North Korean leader claimed that the continental United States and American military bases in the Pacific were now within striking range.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: ‘No One Is Safe’: Zimbabwe Threatens to Seize Farms of Party Defectors
item.media:description: Agrippah Mutambara at his farm on the outskirts of Bindura, Zimbabwe. Like dozens of political figures who have fallen out of favor, he is facing the seizure of his farm.
item.description: In a nation where land is used as a tool of control, many former officials who were beneficiaries of seizures of white-owned farms now find themselves potential victims.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: ‘Burkini’ Inventor Says Sales Have Skyrocketed on Heels of Controversy
item.media:description: Aheda Zanetti, left, inventor of the burkini, said the suit was not meant to be a political statement.
item.description: Aheda Zanetti, who created the full-body swimsuit, said her invention was about “freedom and happiness.”
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Turkey, Sending More Tanks Into Syria, Steps Up Pressure on Kurds
item.media:description: Turkish tanks made their way toward the Syrian town of Jarabulus on Thursday.
item.description: The Turkish military seemed to be succeeding in its broader aims of clearing the border area of Islamic State militants and preventing Kurdish militias from taking more territory.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: North Korea Unveils Netflix-Like Service With Propaganda on Demand
item.media:description: Very few North Koreans are permitted to access the internet.
item.description: Manbang, as it is called, will allow people to watch their country “make a leap forward every day, every hour,” Korean Central Television said.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER and CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Assault on American University in Kabul Killed at Least 13, Officials Say
item.description: Seven students were among the dead at the prestigious Afghan university, where survivors Thursday described an ordeal that lasted nearly 10 hours.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and MOHAMAD FAHIM ABED

item.title: Syria Used Chlorine in Bombs Against Civilians, Report Says
item.media:description: Abu Anas was wounded last year when an artillery shell containing mustard gas, fired by ISIS, hit his family’s home in the Syrian village of al-Marea, in the Aleppo countryside.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: A United Nations investigation says that Syrian military helicopters had used the chemical on at least two occasions, and that ISIS had deployed sulfur mustard, which is poisonous.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Deadly Hospital Bombing Highlights an Escalating War in Yemen
item.media:description: A airstrike on Aug. 15 by Saudi-led forces at a hospital operated by Doctors Without Borders in northwestern Yemen left 19 dead and dozens of others wounded.
item.description: Saudi-led bombings of medical facilities and schools have caused Doctors Without Borders to scale back its efforts, and have caused Congress to put the Obama administration on notice.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI and SHUAIB ALMOSAWA

item.title: Life Expectancy Falls by 5 Years for Syrian Men, New Analysis Finds
item.description: Mortality rates had improved in recent decades, but years of war knocked the life expectancy back to 69 from 74 for men and to 76 from 79 for women.
item.dc:creator: SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.category: Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation

item.title: Sinosphere: Angry Claims and Furious Denials Over Organ Transplants in China
item.media:description: Falun Gong practitioners protested outside the Transplantation Society’s conference in Hong Kong last week.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: The hotly disputed charge that China takes organs from prisoners of conscience gained new prominence as Hong Kong hosted a transplant conference.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Israel Clears Troops in Airstrike Near School in 2014 Gaza War
item.media:description: A Palestinian man carrying an injured child on Aug. 3, 2014, after an Israeli missile struck near a United Nations school in Gaza.
item.description: The military found no wrongdoing in the airstrike, which killed 10 civilians near a United Nations school, and closed six other cases of possible misconduct during the war.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Norway Will Build a Fence at Its Arctic Border With Russia
item.media:description: Two Syrian boys look toward Russia after crossing into Norway by bicycle in Storskog last year.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: The government says a new fence, about 660 feet long and 11 feet high, is needed to tighten security where 5,500 migrants entered Norway last year.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Hunt for Nazi Gold Train Digs Up Nothing but Dirt
item.media:description: An excavation hoping to find a buried Nazi train full of gold, jewels and weapons drew a crowd outside Walbrzych, Poland, last week.
item.media:credit: Mikolaj Nowacki for The New York Times
item.description: Searchers in Walbrzych, Poland, sought a buried train full of gold, jewels and weapons, only to find a natural soil formation. But tourism in the town surged.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: Earthquake in Myanmar Kills 3 and Damages Over 170 Temples
item.description: The quake, which could be felt 400 miles away, caused landslides and damaged temples in Bagan, the heart of Myanmar’s growing tourism industry.
item.dc:creator: WAI MOE

item.title: French Manufacturer Building Indian Submarines Suffers Major Data Leak
item.media:description: The Indian Navy’s first Scorpène submarine at Mazagon Docks, a naval vessel ship-building yard, in Mumbai.
item.description: Detailed plans for stealth submarines being built for the Indian navy have been leaked, leaving France and India scrambling to assess the damage.
item.dc:creator: DAVID JOLLY

item.title: World’s Largest Aircraft Crashes, Gently, in 2nd Test Flight
item.description: Hybrid Air Vehicles, which developed the Airlander 10 airship, said on Twitter that the crew members were “safe and well” after crashing in a field in southern England.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH OLIVENNES

item.title: Why the Italy Quake Was So Severe
item.media:description: The rubble in Amatrice, Italy, on Wednesday. Amatrice, whose mayor lamented that “half the town no longer exists,” has stone churches and other buildings that were constructed centuries ago, when little if anything was known about earthquakes.
item.description: A shallow fault and the presence of centuries-old, unreinforced masonry buildings combined to produce widespread, deadly destruction.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and HENRY FOUNTAIN

item.title: Walter Scheel, Leading Figure in West German Thaw With the East, Dies at 97
item.media:description: Walter Scheel, left, in 1976 with Willy Brandt. Mr. Scheel was foreign minister and deputy chancellor of West Germany under Mr. Brandt, who was chancellor.
item.media:credit: Peter Popp/Deutsche Presse‑Agentur, via Associated Press
item.description: As foreign minister and deputy chancellor under Willy Brandt, Mr. Scheel fostered closer ties with Communist East Germany.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT D. McFADDEN

item.title: North Korean Missile Test Brings Temporary Unity in East Asia
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan, center, welcoming his counterparts from China, Wang Yi, left, and from South Korea, Yun Byung-se, in Tokyo on Wednesday. At the meeting, they criticized North Korea’s missile test.
item.description: Pyongyang’s launch was criticized by China, Japan and South Korea, three nations that have recently had reasons to squabble.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Perm Journal: Moscow Crushes an Uprising, This Time an Artistic One
item.media:description: People near the Boris Matrosov artwork “Happiness Is Just Around the Corner,” on the banks of the Kama River in the center of Perm.
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.description: The city of Perm, once the gateway to the gulag, became a cultural powerhouse in a few short years. Then Vladimir V. Putin returned to the presidency.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Sinosphere: How a Hong Kong Filmmaker Came Across a New Kind of Tibetan Business
item.media:description: A worker inspecting a yak wool scarf at the Norlha textiles workshop in Gansu Province.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: What started as a project to make a corporate video about sustainable development led Ruby Yang to a textile workshop that employed women from Tibetan nomad families.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Canadians Rescue 1,500 Americans Who Veered Off Course on Inflatable Rafts
item.media:description: A customs and border protection boat helped participants of the Float Down in the St. Clair River in Port Huron, Mich.
item.media:credit: Mark R. Rummel/The Times Herald, via Associated Press
item.description: Participants in the Port Huron Float Down in Michigan along the St. Clair River were blown off course by wind gusts, sending some ashore in Canada.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER MELE

item.title: Powerful Earthquake in Italy Kills at Least 241 and Shatters Towns
item.description: An earthquake with a preliminary magnitude of 6.2 struck about 100 miles from Rome, trapping scores under debris and all but destroying some areas.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: What in the World: Holy Water at Home: In India, a Pilgrimage Alternative
item.media:credit: Illustration by Lia Kantrowitz; Photos by saiko3p and Evgeny Karandaev/Shutterstock
item.description: The Indian postal service is using its offices to deliver holy water from the Ganges River, which is usually collected after a barefoot pilgrimage.
item.dc:creator: KAUSHIK SWAMINATHAN

item.title: What in the World: What Poor Nations Need to Get By: Money From Migrants
item.description: Remittances from workers abroad are so important to some countries that one-third of their economies may depend on it, the World Bank says.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: From Sarajevo to Aleppo
item.description: American power has lost credibility, moral conviction has eroded, and a Syrian city bleeds to death.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Editorial: A Stark Reminder of Guantánamo’s Sins
item.media:description: Abu Zubaydah
item.media:credit: U.S. Central Command, via Associated Press
item.description: A glimpse of Abu Zubaydah, whom the Bush administration portrayed as the personification of evil, underscores the travesty at Guantánamo.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Italy’s Fragile Beauty
item.media:description: The town of Amatrice in Italy was hit by a strong earthquake on Wednesday morning.
item.description: It’s too easy to forget that this is a stunning but shaky land.
item.dc:creator: BEPPE SEVERGNINI

item.title: Photo Editors’ Notebook: What Makes the Image of Omran Daqneesh Extraordinary?
item.media:description: The front page of The New York Times on August 19 featured a photograph by Mahmoud Raslan of a 5-year-old boy who was rescued after an airstrike in Aleppo, Syria.
item.description: “It’s a difficult question for even the most seasoned photo editor to answer.”
item.dc:creator: CRAIG ALLEN

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Notebook: How Many Guns Did the U.S. Lose Track of in Iraq and Afghanistan? Hundreds of Thousands.
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers after receiving new rifles from U.S. forces in Baghdad in May 2007.
item.description: A new study shows how the American military failed at the soldier’s most basic responsibility: keeping track of firearms.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Talking to Terrorists
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For once, the conversation wasn’t via social media, and the name the Islamic State defector used was the one on his birth certificate.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
